page.title: 01North Exmoor to Porlock Weir
page.content: This block forms part of the Northern edge of the Exmoor National Park, so popular with walkers. Its highest point (350 metres above sea level) is the South West corner. The moorland falls away steeply to the North and East, firstly to deciduous woodland and then to cultivated grassland. In the East are salt marshes behind the shore which along this coast is of stone and large boulders. The area is sparsely populated. Most people live in the village of Porlock Weir, which has an hotel, an inn, one cafe, three shops, a chapel, small tidal harbour and some pretty cottage many with thatched rooves. At the West end of the block, in the woods, is Culbone Church. The village has one public road from the East with a bus service to Minehead. From the West is a toll road down a steep hill through woods.
